titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Christopher Knowles Papers, 1973-2015 (bulk 1973-1990) MSS.414
titlestmt.author: Sophie Glidden-Lyon.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-14 09:11:49 -0500.

change.item: Edited by Craig Savino to incorporate processed books

did.abstract: The Christopher Knowles Papers contain material relating to the personal and professional life of visual and performing artist Christopher Knowles. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1959, Knowles connected with avant-garde artist Robert Wilson at age 14, after Wilson heard a tape of Knowles speaking the words of his poem "Emily Likes the TV." They collaborated on many performances pieces, most notably "Einstein on the Beach." Knowles has performed internationally and has had his artwork exhibited in both joint and solo shows at galleries including, but not limited to, the Holly Solomon Gallery, Gavin Brown's Enterprise and the Museum of Modern Art. He continues to live and work in New York City.
did.physloc: Some materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Christopher Knowles Papers were donated by Christopher Knowles in October of 2014. The accession number associated with this donation is 2014.414. The 2016 Accretion to the Christopher Knowles Papers was received in February of 2016. The accession number associated with this gift is 2016.012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into 14 series:

SERIES I: Journals
SERIES II: Performance
Subseries A: Performance with Christopher Knowles
Subseries B: Performance without Christopher Knowles
SERIES III: Exhibitions
SERIES IV: Art
SERIES V: Correspondence
SERIES VI: Press
SERIES VII: Personal
SERIES VIII: Photographs
Subseries A: Photographs
Subseries B: Slides
SERIES IX: Sound recordings
SERIES X: Video recordings
SERIES XI: Data storage
SERIES XII: Sound and Video Preservaion
SERIES XIII: 2016 Accession SERIES XIV: Books

The material is arranged chronologically with the exceptions of Series II, Series IX, Series X, and Series XIV which are all arranged alphabetically. Series XIII has not been arranged by an archivist, and remains in the order in which it was received. Original order, as dictated by Knowles and a consulting archivist, was preserved wherever possible. Oversize material is arranged at the end, under the corresponding series number. There is also oversize material in map case 2D. Video and sound recordings, as well as the data storage, were left in the original order as received from the donor and given ID numbers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Brooklyn in 1959, Christopher Knowles is an artist who works within a variety of mediums including performance, poetry, paintings and what are called "typings," visual pieces created using a typewriter, most commonly with the letter "c" for "Christopher". In 1973, at the age of 14, Knowles was approached by avant-garde theater director and artist Robert Wilson, who had heard a tape of Knowles reciting his piece, "Emily Loves the TV" and hoped to collaborate with Knowles. Knowles went, with his parents, to a performance of Wilson's "The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin," where Wilson brought Knowles on stage to perform what would become Knowles' piece, "Emily Likes the TV." This was the beginning of a long friendship which would lead them to collaborate many times over the years, most famously in 1976 on "Einstein on the Beach," which was also in collaboration with composer Philip Glass and choreographer Lucinda Childs. Knowles lived in Wilson's SoHo loft and art studio for a time, working with the Byrd Hoffman School of Byrd's, Wilson's art and performance collective. Other collaborative work included performances with Cindy Lubar and Richard Kostelanetz.

Knowles has had a number of joint and solo shows of his visual art at the Kitchen, the Holly Solomon Gallery, the Byrd Hoffman Studio, Gavin Brown's Enterprise, the Museum of Modern Art, ICA Philadelphia and the Louvre. The Museum of Modern Art acquired some of Knowles' Typings in 2013. Knowles continues to live and work in New York City and travels widely to perform.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Some audiovisual and born-digital materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Christopher Knowles Papers; MSS 414; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2016 an additional donation was received and added to the collection as a separate series in accordance with previous arrangement and descriptions. As there were no original folder titles available for the 2016 accession, these were supplied by an archivist. In 2019, books were processed as an additional series to the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains material pertaining to Knowles professional work as an artist. However, much of that work was done as a young adolescent, which is reflected throughout the collection. His journals are a repository for his artwork as well as his personal life and contain reflections of his exhibited or performed art. There is material relating to the many performances in which he took part, including programs, press, reviews, source material, scripts, photographs and publicity. Some of the performances include "Einstein on the Beach," "The $ Value of Man," "A Letter for Queen Victoria," "Dialog/Curious George," and "Parzival." Many of these were collaborations with Robert Wilson. In addition to the paper material related to his performances, there are video and sound recordings of shows, as well as recordings that Knowles used as a part of his performances.

Knowles produced a large portfolio of paintings and drawings in addition to his performance art. The collection includes material documenting his exhibitions, both domestic and international, including press, gallery cards, exhibit catalogs and correspondence. There are photographs of his exhibited work, as well as slides, in addition to marker, pen and crayon drawings. Notably, Knowles created what are called "Typings," made with a typewriter and most commonly using the letter "c" to create designs and images. This collection contains quite a few typings, as well as typewritten poetry and some prose.

Correspondence includes letters, cards and postcards both sent and received by Knowles. Notable correspondence includes Jasper Johns, John Cage, Robert Wilson and Cindy Lubar. Knowles also designed and created a large number of birthday and father's day cards, as well as invitations to his shows and his own birthday parties.

Photographs include many taken of Knowles and his family, as well of images of his art. There are photographs of performances and rehearsals, international exhibits and shows, in addition to family vacations and his home in Brooklyn. There is a small amount of material relating to Knowles' personal life, including medical and educational information and resumes.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Books included in this collection have been removed and will be cataloged in BobCat. They will be available via a BobCat search for "Christopher Knowles."

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically, with undated material at the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains journals and sketchbooks filled by Christopher Knowles. Many contain work referencing larger complete artworks, such as "Curious George," which was a collaboration with Robert Wilson. Done mostly in marker or pen, the journals also include many of Knowles "Top Ten" song lists, which he created listening to WABC DJs. Occasionally, the journals contain typewritten text that was then tapped into the blank book. There are also two books created by Knowles as a young child, with the aid of a parent, using text, drawing and photographs. Additionally, a few of the journals include additions by collaborator Cindy Lubar and Robert Wilson.

did.unittitle: The 6 People in the Knowles Family
The New York by Chris Knowles
The Book About Spring, Summer, Fall and Winter

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically, with multiple occurances of the same performance arranged chronologically. Subseries A contains material for performances to which Knowles contributed directly. Subseries B contains material relating to performances in which Knowles was not immediately involved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Christopher Knowles' performance art. This includes programs, photographs, source material and posters, as well as some correspondence and press. Many of these performances were written by or originally conceived by others, most prominently Robert Wilson, but Knowles often contributed text or set design, if he was not performing in the piece itself.

arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically with undated material at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to Christopher Knowles' exhibitions of his artwork. This includes joint and solo exhibitions. The artwork exhibited includes paintings and "typings." The material includes publicity, catalogs, invitations, and photographs as well as some press and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically with undated material at the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains original art by Christopher Knowles. This includes drawings and typings as well as poetry and prose. Some of the material relates to completed works of art like his collaboration with Robert Wilson, "Dialog/Curious George," as well as a few pieces that were exhibited in galleries. However, the majority of the material exists independently and should not necessarily be considered complete artworks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically, with undated material at the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence both sent and received by Christopher Knowles. It includes many cards and post cards, as well as professional correspondence concerning the exhibition and sale of his artwork, arranging performances and travel. There is correspondence between him and his parents, Jasper Johns, Jay Moses, Robert Wilson, Cindy Lubar and the Holly Solomon Gallery.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically, with undated material at the back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains press relating to Christopher Knowles artwork and performances. Publications include, but are not limited to, the New York Times, Artforum, the Village Voice, Andy Warhol's Interview, The Guardian and the Boston Globe. Reviews of performances, publications and gallery shows are included here, as well interviews and profiles.

did.unittitle: Life and Times of Joseph Stalin Dance Magazine
A Letter for Queen Victoria, Vogue
Poetry Reading at St. Marks Church
Cue: Official Magazine of Theta Alpha Phi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains a small amount of material that is not directly related to Christopher Knowles' professional life as an artist. Most material dates from early childhood to adolescence and includes medical material such as neurological exams, as well as information concerning his early education. The only exception to this is the "biography file" which contains resumes in addition to material concerning his family and friends.

did.unittitle: Christopher Knowles earnings via Byrd Hoffman Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a folder list compiled by the consulting archivist who worked with this collection prior to its arrival at Fales Library. It should be noted that this list will not correspond to the current arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series includes professional photos of Knowles' artwork and exhibitions, as well as photographs of performances, Knowles' family and his travels for both professional and personal reasons. There are a small number of postcards included in the boxed photos.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by original order and in two subseries. Subseries A includes photographs in two binders as well as a box containing photographs arranged and labeled by Knowles, with the aid of a consulting archivist. Where possible, labels were put in place by Knowles, or transcribed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series includes video recordings of performances in which Christopher Knowles took part. This includes performances in which he acted, like Parzival, but also performances for which he wrote text, or designed the set or the sound. They are largely in VHS format, with some DVDs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged adhering as close to original order as is possible.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged adhering as close to original order as is possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series includes sound recordings collected or made by Christopher Knowles. The material exists largely in tape cassette format, with one audio reel. Much of the material was used in Knowles performances and are recordings of his own voice, recordings he made off the television and radio, or of ambient noise. There are also sound recordings of his performances.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Audio materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.
